title-group.article-title: The Role of Target Leverage in Security Issues and Repurchases*

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2004 by the Journal of Business. All rights reserved.

abstract.p: The paper examines whether security issues and repurchases adjust the capital structure toward the target. The time‐series patterns of debt ratios imply that only debt reductions are initiated to offset the accumulated deviation from target leverage. The importance of target leverage in earlier debt‐equity choice studies is driven by the subsample of equity issues accompanied by debt reductions. Unlike debt issues and reductions, equity issues and repurchases have no significant lasting effect on capital structure. Therefore, even firms that have target debt ratios can engage in timing the equity market.

fn.p: I would like to thank an anonymous referee and seminar participants at Baruch College for valuable comments and advice.

sec.label: I.
sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The concept of target capital structure plays an important role in many models of corporate financing. According to the static trade‐off theory (Modigliani and Miller,1963), for example, firms optimize their capital structures by trading off the tax benefits of debt financing against the costs of financial distress. In the agency‐theoretical models (e.g., Jensen and Meckling1976; Stulz1990;Hart and Moore1995), target leverage minimizes the sum of the agency costs of managerial discretion associated with equity financing and the agency costs of debt, such as the costs of underinvestment (Myers1977) and asset substitution (Jensen and Meckling1976). In signaling models (e.g., Ross1977), target leverage is determined by a trade‐off between the benefits associated with a higher market value and the costs of credibly signaling to the market that the value is high.

The existing empirical evidence on target leverage is mixed. Studies of the determinants of corporate debt ratios (e.g., Titman and Wessels1988; Rajan and Zingales1995; Graham1996a; Hovakimian, Opler, and Titman2001) generally support the notion that firms strive to maintain target capital structures. For example, observed leverage ratios relate to firm characteristics such as size, growth opportunities, collateral (liquidation) value of assets, and the marginal tax rate in a manner consistent with the predictions of static trade‐off and agency theories.

Another group of studies (e.g., Marsh1982;Jalilvand and Harris1984; MacKie‐Mason1990; Bayless and Chaplinsky1991; Hovakimian et al.2001) examines how firm characteristics affect the issuing (repurchasing) firm's debt/equity choice. Consistent with the target leverage hypothesis, these studies find that the probability of issuing debt rather than equity is inversely related to the amount of excess (relative to the target) leverage.

On the other hand, Shyam‐Sunder and Myers (1999) report that a simple pecking order model1outperforms the target adjustment model in explaining the time‐series variation in debt ratios. Furthermore, the importance of firm characteristics identified in the earlier studies as determinants of firms' debt ratios and their financing choices can often be explained by factors unrelated to target leverage. For example, these studies find that firms with high market‐to‐book ratios tend to issue equity and have low financial leverage. If market‐to‐book ratio is a proxy for firms' growth opportunities, then this result is consistent with the “debt overhang” hypothesis that high‐growth firms have low target debt ratios (Myers1977). Alternatively, managers may believe that their shares are undervalued when their stock price is low relative to accounting measures of value, that is, when their market‐to‐book ratio is low. This may make managers reluctant to issue equity, resulting in higher debt ratios than in otherwise similar firms.2

Indirect evidence on target leverage, provided by studies of stock market reactions to corporate financing events, is also inconclusive. Masulis (1980), Asquith and Mullins (1986), and Smith (1986) find that stock prices react favorably to announcements of leverage‐increasing transactions but unfavorably to announcements of leverage‐decreasing transactions. These results are not consistent with the hypothesis that firms adjust toward the optimal (from the shareholders' point of view) capital structure when they reduce their leverage. Nevertheless, these results can be reconciled with the target leverage hypothesis once we recognize that the managerial target debt ratio may deviate from the shareholders' optimum.3

The current study examines empirically whether corporate financing behavior is consistent with the target leverage hypothesis. Like earlier studies of debt‐equity choice, the current paper focuses on instances when firms issue or repurchase debt or equity. The paper is particularly closely related to the recent studies by Hovakimian et al. (2001) and Lie (2002). Using several alternative proxies for target debt ratio, Hovakimian et al. (2001) find that the deviation from the target is an important determinant of the debt vs. equity choice for firms that raise outside financing but even more so for firms that repurchase some of their outstanding securities. They further report that the size of an issue is not affected by the deviation from the target, while the size of a repurchase is.

This paper extends and complements the analysis of the differential impact of the deviation from target leverage on corporate financing choices, presented in Hovakimian et al. (2001). Specifically, we examine how the deviation from the target affects each type of security issue or repurchase. It is possible, for example, that firms issue (retire) debt primarily when they want to adjust their leverage toward a higher (lower) target, but that they issue (repurchase) equity primarily to take advantage of favorable market conditions.4Debt‐equity choice analysis, such as one used in Hovakimian et al. (2001), does not allow us to test for such a possibility. We test the target leverage hypothesis separately for equity issues, debt issues, equity repurchases, and debt reductions. We do so by examining the pattern of changes in leverage ratios and their deviations from target ratios around these corporate financing events.

This empirical approach is similar to the analysis in Lie (2002). Unlike Lie (2002), who focuses on self‐tender offers, we examine a wider range of transactions, consisting of debt issues, equity issues, debt reductions, as well as equity repurchases that include not only self‐tender offers but also open market repurchases.

The paper extends the earlier studies in a number of other ways. One contribution of the paper is that it formulates and separately tests two forms of the target leverage hypothesis. The finding that the deviation from target leverage is an important determinant of the issuing (repurchasing) firm's debt/equity choice (Marsh1982; Jalilvand and Harris1984; MacKie‐Mason1990; Bayless and Chaplinsky1991; Hovakimian et al.2001) is consistent with two descriptions of corporate financing behavior. According to one description, which we call the target‐adjustment hypothesis, firms issue and repurchase securities to offset the deviation from the target accumulated prior to the transaction.5This description implies that the deviation from target leverage determines the type, the size, and the timing of a security issue or a repurchase.

However, the evidence from the debt‐equity choice studies is also consistent with an alternative, weaker form of the target leverage hypothesis, which we call the debt‐equity choice hypothesis. Under this hypothesis, the deviation from the target determines only the form of financing chosen to minimize the ex‐post deviation from the target leverage ratio. The timing and the size of security issues, in this case, are determined by other factors, such as financing needs. The debt vs. equity choice analysis used in earlier studies cannot differentiate between the two forms of the target leverage hypothesis. Analysis of the dynamics of changes in debt ratios and their deviations from the target around security issues and repurchases allows us to test each form of the target leverage hypothesis separately.

Our main results are as follows. Among transactions examined in the paper, only debt reductions offset the deviation from target leverage accumulated prior to the transaction. Debt reductions follow periods of rising excess leverage, which drops as a result of the transaction and remains low throughout the 3‐year postevent period studied in the paper.

Unlike debt reductions, debt issues do not reduce the deviation from the target debt ratio. The pre‐debt‐issue deviation from the target is essentially zero. The issuance of debt increases rather than reduces the deviation from the target. Nevertheless, some of our results indicate a possibility that firms issue debt in response to increases in their target debt ratios, which our proxies for the target are unable to capture. Specifically, we find that debt issues induce economically and statistically significant increases in leverage and the resulting debt ratios remain high for at least 3 years after the issue.

Our results also imply that offsetting the accumulated deviation from the target is not the primary reason for issuing or repurchasing equity. Equity repurchases follow periods of rising leverage deficit, but they fail to offset any significant portion of the accumulated deviation from the target. Equity issuers are underlevered rather than overlevered prior to the issue. The issuance of equity increases rather than reduces the issuer's deviation from the target. Furthermore, the reductions in leverage induced by equity issues are small in magnitude and transitory. These reductions are completely offset by the end of the second year after the issue.

To better identify which transactions are and which are not affected by the deviation from target leverage, we differentiate pure issues and repurchases from mixed transactions, where an issue of one security is accompanied by a repurchase of another security. The paper shows that these distinctions are important. Specifically, it demonstrates that the importance of the deviation from target leverage in the debt vs. equity issuance choice regressions reported in the earlier studies is driven by the subsample of equity issues accompanied by debt reductions. The effect disappears when pure issues are studied separately. Overall, multivariate analysis of the security issue (repurchase) choice using logistic regressions confirms our event‐study results on the role of target leverage. These regressions also show that a firm's market performance has an important impact on its security issue (repurchase) choice, implying that the timing of these transactions may be driven by market conditions.

The findings that equity issues and repurchases do not offset the accumulated deviation from the target and they are timed to market conditions do not necessarily imply that the capital structure is irrelevant for firms that issue or repurchase equity. First, our results support the weak form of the target leverage hypothesis for these firms. An average equity issuer (repurchaser) would deviate further from the target, if it raised (repurchased) a similar amount of debt instead. Furthermore, our results indicate that these firms are able to pursue market‐timing strategies because the deviations (and the costs of deviating) from the target induced by equity transactions are small and transitory. Unlike debt issues and reductions, equity issues and repurchases have no significant lasting effect on the firm's capital structure.6

The paper proceeds as follows. Section II describes the sample. Section III examines the hypothesis that firms adjust their leverage ratios to offset the accumulated deviation from the target. Section IV tests the weaker hypothesis that the type of the issue is chosen to minimize the deviation from the target leverage. Section V verifies our results using alternative proxies for target leverage. Section VI tests the target leverage hypothesis in multivariate settings. Section VII summarizes our findings and concludes the paper.

fn.p: According to the pecking order theory of Myers and Majluf (1984), firms do not attempt to maintain a particular capital structure. Instead, information asymmetry between better‐informed managers and less‐informed investors creates an environment where existing shareholders prefer internal funds to external financing. Existing shareholders prefer debt to equity when external financing must be raised.

A number of papers provide evidence consistent with this story. Baker and Wurgler (2004) find that firms time equity markets and that this timing has a long‐term effect on the firm's capital structure. Jenter (2004) finds a positive association between high market‐to‐book ratios and both insider selling and equity issuance. Heron and Lie (2002) find that the positive association between market‐to‐book ratios and the likelihood of an equity offering is limited to primary and combination (primary and secondary) issues and does not extend to secondary, rights, and shelf issues.

Zwiebel (1996) presents a model where leverage is costly for managers because it increases the probability of bankruptcy and subsequent dismissal. However, high leverage may also be beneficial for managers, because it allows them to precommit to act in the interest of shareholders and thereby avoid takeover challenges. The manager's target capital structure balances these costs and benefits. In this model, an exogenous decline in the probability of a takeover would reduce the manager's target leverage ratio and induce him or her to decrease the firm's leverage. Such a reduction would weaken the manager's incentives to act in the interest of the shareholders and induce a negative stock price reaction.

In a survey of 392 CFOs, Graham and Harvey (2001) find that EPS dilution, stock under‐or overvaluation, and recent price increases top the list of factors affecting the firm's decision to issue common stock. The top factors affecting the choice of the debt level, on the other hand, are financial flexibility, credit rating, and the volatility of the firm's earnings.
Such a behavior is predicted by dynamic models of capital structure, such as those proposed by Fischer, Heinkel, and Zechner (1989), Leland (1994), and Goldstein, Ju, and Leland (2001).
This result is not consistent with the hypothesis that capital structure is the cumulative outcome of attempts to time the equity market (Baker and Wurgler2002).

sec.label: II.
sec.title: Sample Selection and Description
sec.p: The sample of debt and equity issues is obtained from the SDC's New Issues database. Repurchases are identified using annual firm level data from the Standard and Poors Compustat Industrial, Full Coverage, and Research files. We focus only on instances in which substantial amounts of common equity or debt are issued or repurchased. Therefore, only observations with net issue (repurchase) size greater or equal to 5% of the preissue book value of total assets are included in the sample.7Following the practice of earlier studies, we exclude firm‐years when both debt and equity were issued or repurchased. We also exclude financial firms, because their capital structures are likely to be significantly different from the capital structures of other firms in our sample. The resulting sample includes 3,712 firm‐years with security issues and 12,533 firm‐years with security repurchases and covers the 1980–1998 period.

The results suggest that both equity issuers and debt issuers are somewhat overlevered relative to their industry peers. The excess book leverage is statistically different from zero, although it is small in magnitude (+0.5% for equity issuers and +0.0% for debt issuers). The excess market leverage is statistically indistinguishable from zero for both types of firms. Firms that repurchase equity are underlevered. The excess book (market) leverage is −5.4% (−3.3%). The book and market debt ratios of firms that redeem debt, on the other hand, are about 10% higher than the corresponding industry medians. These excess leverage ratios are all statistically significant.

The transaction‐type subsamples represented in panel A overlap. Some 42% of equity issuers retire substantial amounts of debt in the same year. These observations appear in both equity issue and debt reduction subsamples. Similarly, about 8% of debt issuers repurchase equity in the same year. These observations appear in both debt issue and equity repurchase subsamples. To better understand how leverage affects or is affected by each transaction, we need to separate such complex transactions from the cases in which a single security is issued or repurchased.

Panel B partitions our sample into six transaction‐type subsamples by creating two additional categories for equity issues accompanied by debt reductions and debt issues accompanied by equity repurchases. The partition reveals economically and statistically significant differences between firms initiating pure issues and repurchases and firms issuing one security while repurchasing another. For example, pure equity issuers have lower debt ratios, are smaller, and have higher market‐to‐book ratios and cash levels than equity issuers that retire debt. Furthermore, pure equity issuers are significantly underlevered, while equity issuers that retire debt are overlevered prior to the issue. Firms that retire debt are significantly more levered, have lower ROAs, market‐to‐book ratios, and stock returns than firms that retire debt and issue equity. Pure debt issuers are significantly more levered, are smaller, and have lower market‐to‐book ratios and cash levels than debt issuers that repurchase equity. Pure equity repurchasers are significantly less levered prior to the repurchase than repurchasers that issue debt. Pure repurchasers are also smaller and have higher cash levels.

The results in panel B suggest that the importance of target leverage may vary depending on whether a security issue (repurchase) is accompanied by a repurchase (issue) of another security. Therefore, the analysis that follows differentiates between such transactions.

Net debt issued (retired) is calculated as the change in the book value of the total debt (Item 9 + Item 34). The procedure follows Hovakimian et al. (2001).

sec.label: III.
sec.title: The Target‐Adjustment Hypothesis
sec.p: In this section, we test the target‐adjustment hypothesis that follows from the dynamic capital structure models, such as those proposed by Fischer et al. (1989), Leland (1994), and Goldstein et al. (2001). These models imply that firms let their leverage fluctuate over time as long as it stays within an endogenously determined range. Only when the range boundaries are crossed, do firms adjust their leverage ratios toward a target within the range. Such behavior arises as a result of a dynamic optimal capital structure policy that balances the benefits of debt financing with its costs in an environment where capital structure adjustments are costly. Empirically, such behavior implies that security issues and repurchases either offset the deviation from the target accumulated prior to the transaction or respond to shifts in target leverage.

Our first group of tests examines whether the time‐series patterns of leverage ratios around leverage‐decreasing and leverage‐increasing transactions are consistent with this scenario. Specifically, if corporate financing transactions were initiated to offset the accumulated deviation from the target, we would expect the deviation from the target to reach its peak right before the transaction and drop significantly as a result of the transaction.

We test this hypothesis using the industry median leverage as a proxy for the target debt ratio.8Numerous studies (e.g., Bradley, Jarrell, and Kim,1984) have documented strong industry effects in the cross‐section of corporate leverage ratios, suggesting that the industry average may be a reasonable proxy for the target leverage ratio. Nevertheless, the results inTable 1demonstrate that equity (debt) issuers are systematically less (more) levered than their industry counterparts. For such firms, our proxy may be biased. Therefore, in section V, we reexamine our results using regression‐based proxies for the target, similar to those used by Hovakimian et al. (2001) and Lie (2001).

We also use an alternative testing strategy that does not require the use of any proxy for the target. Under the null hypothesis that firms issue and repurchase securities to offset the accumulated deviation from the target leverage, the leverage ratio observed right before the transaction can serve as a proxy for the boundary that triggers the capital structure adjustment. It is the upper boundary for leverage‐decreasing transactions and the lower boundary for leverage‐increasing transactions. Therefore, we would expect the leverage ratios observed right before (year –1) leverage‐decreasing transactions to be higher and the ratios observed right before (year –1) leverage‐increasing transactions to be lower than the leverage ratios in other pre‐and post‐transaction years.

The preceding discussion assumes that the target ratio and the corresponding boundaries are stable over the examination period and adjustments are triggered by changes in firms' leverage ratios due to accumulated earnings and losses. A leverage adjustment may also be triggered by a shift in the target and the corresponding boundaries, in which case the pretransaction deviation from the old target is irrelevant. If leverage adjustments were induced by such shifts, then for leverage‐increasing transactions, we would expect the leverage ratios in posttransaction years to be higher than the pretransaction ratios. For leverage‐decreasing transactions, we would expect the posttransaction leverage ratios to be lower than the pretransaction ratios. The hypothesis of a shift in the target is rejected if these patterns are not observed. We should note however, that posttransaction leverage ratios might differ significantly from pretransaction ratios for other reasons as well. This can happen even with a constant target; if for example, the drift away from the target is very slow. A large difference between post‐and preissue leverage ratios may also indicate that these firms do not have target leverage ratios.

fn.p: The industries are identified based on their four‐digit SIC codes.

The results for pure equity issues (panel A) reject the hypothesis that firms issue equity to offset excess leverage accumulated in preissue years. First, equity issuers are significantly underlevered rather than overlevered prior to the issue. The median deviation from the industry benchmark is significantly negative in each preissue year. Second, neither the debt ratio of a typical equity issuer nor its deviation from the target increase between years −3 and −1. Both changes are not significantly different from zero.

The results also reject the hypothesis that equity is issued in response to a downward shift in target leverage ratio. The issuance of equity in year 0 significantly reduces the median issuer's debt ratio. However, this decline is offset by an upward trend in leverage observed in the postissue years. The median decline in leverage between years −1 and 0 is 2.8%. The median change between years −1 and +3 is zero. The transitory nature of the change in leverage is inconsistent with the hypothesis that firms issue equity to adjust their debt ratio to a new, lower target level.

The results in panel B are consistent with the hypothesis that firms retire debt to offset accumulated excess leverage. Unlike the firms in panel A, these firms experience a significant upward drift in leverage during the 3 preevent years. Between years −3 and −1, the leverage increases by 3.7%. The increase is statistically significant at the 1% level. As expected under the null hypothesis, the deviation from the industry median is significantly positive in each preissue year and is the highest in year −1. The trend of increasing excess leverage is reversed as a result of the debt reduction in year 0. Both the leverage ratio and its deviation from the industry target drop in the year when debt is retired. The drop is significant not only statistically but also economically. The median decline in leverage is 7.8% and the median decline in excess leverage is 7.0%.

The leverage ratios and the deviations from the industry medians in panel B are lower at the end of each of years +1 through +3 than they were in years −1, −2, or −3. The change in leverage between years −1 and +3 is a statistically significant −9.4%. The change in excess leverage is a statistically significant −6.8%. Therefore, the hypothesis of a downward shift in the target cannot be rejected.

For firms that simultaneously issue equity and retire debt (panel C), the time‐series profile of leverage is similar to that in panel B. Thus, debt reductions serve to offset the accumulated excess leverage, regardless of whether they are financed with equity issues.

To summarize, the presented evidence is inconsistent with the hypothesis that equity issues offset excess leverage accumulated prior to the issue. Changes in leverage caused by equity issuance are economically small and transitory and, therefore, unlikely to be induced by a shift in target leverage ratio. Such changes are also unlikely to be directly responsible for the observed strong market reaction to these events. In contrast, target leverage appears to be an important factor when firms retire debt. Debt reductions follow periods of increasing excess leverage and result in large, long‐term declines in leverage ratios. Finally, the results show that the time‐series pattern of leverage changes around equity issues accompanied by debt reductions is very similar to that around pure debt reductions but is very different from that around pure equity issues. This implies that it is important to control for the presence of debt reductions when studying the determinants and effects of equity issues.

fn.p: We report the medians because these are less sensitive to the presence of extreme observations. The advantage of the Wilcoxon test is that it is nonparametric, i.e., its test statistics are not based on a particular assumed distribution of the underlying data.

The results in panel A are inconsistent with the hypothesis that firms issue debt to offset the accumulated leverage deficit. We find no evidence that debt issuers are underlevered. In each of the 3 preissue years, the excess leverage is positive and statistically significant, although trivial in economic terms. Nor do we find any evidence of a significant leverage decline in the preissue years. The difference between years −3 and −1 is not significantly different from zero. The issuance of debt in year 0 significantly increases the median issuer's debt ratio. The median increase in leverage is 7.8% and the median increase in excess leverage is 7.0%.

The leverage ratios in all 3 post‐issue years remain significantly higher than the leverage ratios in any of the pre‐issue years. The increase in leverage between year −1 and year +3 is a statistically significant 5.8%. Postissue leverage ratios are also significantly higher than the contemporaneous industry medians. These results seem consistent with the hypothesis that firms issue debt in response to a shift to a higher target, which substantially exceeds the industry norm. Unfortunately, the results are also consistent with an alternative hypothesis that these firms do not issue debt to move closer to their target leverage ratios.

The time‐series pattern for equity repurchases is presented in panel B. We find evidence of some leverage deficit accumulation in the prerepurchase period. Between years −3 and −1, both the leverage ratio and its deviation from the industry target decline by 0.6%. The median leverage deficit before the repurchase is a statistically significant −5.9%. However, the repurchase itself fails to offset this deficit.10The median repurchaser's leverage ratio does not change as a result of the transaction. The last result is inconsistent with the hypothesis that firms repurchase equity to offset a previously accumulated leverage deficit. Nor it is consistent with the hypothesis that firms repurchase equity to adjust their leverage ratio to a new, higher target.

The repurchasers' results are not consistent with the significant increases in leverage of firms that repurchase equity via self‐tender offers reported in Lie (2002). A number of important differences between the two studies can explain the diverging results. First, Lie (2002) examines self‐tender offers only. Equity repurchases in our study include both self‐tenders and open market repurchases. Given the difference in the number of repurchases (1904 in this study vs. 286 in Lie2002), it is likely that the current sample is dominated by open market repurchases. This may explain the differences in the characteristics of the two samples. Specifically, the median prerepurchase market leverage in Lie (2002) is 0.220 for nondefensive self‐tenders and 0.288 for defensive ones. In our sample, the median market leverage is a mere 0.042. This alone could explain the differences in the results of the two studies. Repurchase of the same fraction of outstanding shares would produce much more dramatic changes in firms with high prerepurchase leverage than in firms with low leverage.

For example, a repurchase of equity in the amount of 8.6% of total assets (the median repurchase size intable 1) would change the leverage from 0.072 (the median pre‐repurchase leverage intable 3) to 0.079. Because of confounding effects, such as earnings retained in the year of repurchase, the actual median post‐repurchase leverage intable 3is 0.072. Therefore, one could argue that, without a repurchase, the firms leverage would be lower by about 0.7%. Nevertheless, it does not seem plausible that firms repurchase equity to adjust their debt ratio by such a small amount, especially given that they do not seem to care about a 5.7% leverage deficit left after the repurchase.

Note, finally, that equity repurchases accompanied by debt issuance exhibit significant increases in their debt ratios in our sample. Lie (2002) does not differentiate between repurchasers that issue debt and those that do not. This may also account for some of the differences between our results.

Panel C presents the results for debt issuers who simultaneously repurchase equity. The results are very similar to those for pure debt issuers. The results reject the hypothesis that firms issue debt to offset the accumulated leverage deficit. The results fail to reject the hypothesis that firms issue debt in response to increases in their target debt ratios.

To summarize, the evidence is inconsistent with the hypothesis that firms issue debt to offset leverage deficit accumulated in preissue years. Our results suggest that firms may be issuing debt in response to increases in their target leverage ratios. However, the possibility that debt issuers have no target debt ratio cannot be ruled out. Equity repurchases follow periods of economically small but statistically significant declines in leverage. However, the repurchases do not result in significant changes in leverage. We conclude that target leverage does not play a major role in equity repurchases.

fn.p: In the presented analysis, we do not control for the confounding effects such as earnings retained in the year of the repurchase. This will be done in the next section of the paper.

sec.label: C.
sec.title: Sensitivity Analysis
sec.p: We check the robustness of the discussed results in a number of ways. First, we repeated the analysis using market rather than book leverage. The qualitative results did not change. Second, we confirmed that the time‐series patterns for the mean leverage ratios are similar to the patterns for the medians intables 2and3. Next, we repeated our analysis for the subsample of industrial firms (SIC codes 1000 through 3999). These firms constitute approximately 60% of our sample. The results remained qualitatively unchanged. We also verified that the patterns intables 2and3hold when we restrict the sample to firms that did not have a transaction of the same type within the last 3 years. The presence of transactions of the same type executed by the same firm in consecutive years creates overlapping and, therefore, correlated observations in the tests of multiyear changes in leverage ratios. This interdependence may invalidate our test statistics, which are based on the assumption of independence. However, the results, including the significance levels, did not change when overlapping observations were excluded. Excluding observations with similar transactions in previous years may also have negative consequences. For example, excluding equity issues that precede other equity issues may bias pre‐equity‐issue changes in leverage ratios.11Because of these reasons, we report our results for the full sample including overlapping observations.

Our results for firms that issue equity without retiring debt and firms that repurchase equity may be driven by the subsample of these firms that had no debt prior to the transaction. Such firms, obviously, could not have experienced changes in leverage prior to and as a result of the transaction. Therefore, we repeated our analysis excluding equity issuers and repurchasers that had no debt in their pretransaction capital structure. The qualitative results did not change.

The differences between different types of transactions intables 2and3could arise if some transactions were concentrated in industries where the cost of deviating from the industry norm was low and others in industries where the cost of deviating from the industry norm was high. To check this, we calculated the variance of leverage ratios for each four‐digit SIC code. We then repeated our analysis separately for firms in low‐variance and high‐variance industries. While deviations from the target are somewhat higher in the high‐variance group, the time‐series patterns observed intables 2and3hold for both subsamples.

fn.p: A sample of firms with no equity issues (but some debt issues) during several preceding years may include a disproportionately large number of firms that experienced increases in leverage.

sec.label: IV.
sec.title: The Debt‐Equity Choice Hypothesis
sec.p: The target‐adjustment hypothesis formulated in the preceding section implies that the deviation from the target leverage determines the type, size, and timing of a security issue or a repurchase. Our empirical results, however, suggest that the timing and the size of debt issues, equity issues, and equity repurchases are unrelated to the deviation from the target. In this section, we test a weaker form of the target leverage hypothesis. Under this hypothesis, the deviation from the target determines only the form of financing chosen to minimize the ex‐post deviation from the target leverage ratio. The timing and the size of security issues, in this case, are determined by other factors, such as financing needs. Empirically, the debt‐equity choice hypothesis implies that the absolute deviation from the target under the chosen form of financing should be lower than the absolute deviation from the target that would have resulted if the alternative form of financing were chosen.

To test this hypothesis, we construct two projections of posttransaction debt ratios. Projection I is the pretransaction leverage ratio adjusted for the effect of the issue (repurchase), calculated for both the actual and the alternative security. For example, for equity issues, Projection I with actual transaction is calculated as the preissue debt/(pre‐issue assets + issue amount). Projection I with alternative transaction, in this case, is the postissue leverage ratio projected under the assumption that the firm issues debt rather than equity, calculated as the [(pre‐issue debt + issue amount)/(pre‐issue assets + issue amount)].12For debt issues, the latter calculation provides the projected debt ratio with the actual transaction (debt), while the former calculation provides the projection with the alternative transaction (equity).

The projected post transaction deviations from target leverage, Projection I–Tgt, with actual and alternative transactions are presented in columns (2) and (3) oftable 4. For comparison, the actual pretransaction deviation from the target is presented in column (1). For equity issuers, the projected deviation from the target is −5.8%. If these firms were to issue debt, they would become overlevered by 23.1%. The difference between absolute deviations from the target under debt financing and under equity financing is statistically and economically significant. These results imply that the hypothesis that equity issuers choose the form of financing that minimizes the ex‐post deviation from the target cannot be rejected. Table 4

For debt issuers, the picture emerging fromtable 4is different. Issuing debt would make these firms overlevered by 14.2%. If they were to issue equity, debt issuers would become underlevered by 3.7%. The difference between absolute deviations from the target under debt financing and under equity financing is statistically and economically significant. Therefore, the hypothesis that debt issuers choose the form of financing that minimizes the ex‐post deviation from target leverage is rejected.

The results for firms that retire debt are consistent with the hypothesis that the ex‐post deviation from the target would be higher had these firms repurchased equity instead. The projected post‐debt‐reduction deviation from the target is 0.3%. If these firms were to repurchase equity, the postevent deviation would be 15.1%. These results are not surprising given that the earlier results for debt reductions (seetable 2) were consistent with the strong form of the target leverage hypothesis.

Similarly, for equity repurchasers, the results are consistent with the hypothesis that the postevent deviation from the target would be higher had these firms retired debt. The projected deviation from the target is −4.9% if the firms repurchase equity and −16.9% if they retire debt. The difference between absolute deviations from the target is statistically significant.

Projection I implicitly assumes that managers ignore the changes in leverage ratios induced by other factors, such as the profits accumulated between years −1 and 0. To the extent that these effects are predictable, they may be taken into account when managers choose between issuing (repurchasing) debt or equity. As a sensitivity test, we constructed a second proxy for the projected post‐transaction debt ratio, Projection II, assuming that managers fully anticipate the changes in debt ratios between years −1 and 0. Under such an assumption, the projected post‐transaction leverage with the actual transaction is simply the actual post‐transaction leverage ratio. The deviation of this value from the target is presented in column (4) oftable 4. The deviation from the target of the projected post‐transaction leverage with alternative transaction is presented in column (5). For equity transactions, Projection II with alternative transaction is calculated as the (post‐issue debt + issue amount)/post‐issue assets. For debt transactions, this value is calculated as the [(post‐issue debt–issue amount)/post‐issue assets.] If the managers take an even longer‐term view, they may consider the debt ratios projected for the year +1 when deciding to issue (repurchase) debt or equity. Columns (6) and (7) present the deviations from the target of the actual and the projected (with alternative transaction) debt ratios at the end of the fiscal year +1.

The results for both year 0 and year +1 confirm our earlier conclusions. Firms that issue equity, reduce debt, or repurchase equity choose the financing instrument that minimizes the projected posttransaction deviation from the target. On the other hand, firms issue debt even though the projected postissue deviation from the target would be lower if they issued equity instead.

The robustness of the qualitative results intable 4is confirmed when we examine market‐value leverage, means of the leverage ratios, limit the analysis to the subsample of manufacturing firms, remove overlapping observations from our tests, exclude firms with no debt from the subsamples of equity issuers and repurchasers, or split the sample into subsamples of firms from industries with high and low variance of leverage ratios.

For our final robustness check, we use a different measure of leverage, defined as the firm's leverage percentile within a four‐digit SIC industry group. We see fromtable 1that our sample leverage ratios are generally less than 0.5 and the debt and equity issues are generally larger than the deviations from the target leverage. For such values, issuing debt would very likely result in a higher ex‐post deviation from the target than issuing the same amount of equity.13To make sure that the results intable 4are not just the reflection of the mathematical properties of leverage ratios, we repeated the analysis using the leverage percentiles. The results confirmed the findings reported intable 4.

To summarize, with the exception of debt issuers, the hypothesis that firms choose the form of financing to minimize the ex‐post deviation from the target leverage ratio could not be rejected. An average debt issuer remains closer to the target if it issued equity, which is inconsistent with the hypothesis. On the other hand, an average firm retiring debt deviates further from the target, if it repurchases the same amount of equity. An average equity issuer (repurchaser) in our sample deviates further from the target leverage, if it raises (repurchases) the same amount of financing in the form of debt. Therefore, even though firms do not issue and repurchase equity to adjust their leverage toward the target, they tend to prefer equity transactions because these transactions induce relatively small deviations from their relatively low targets.

fn.p: The issue amount is the actual net debt or equity issued. Repurchases are treated as negative issues.

As an illustration, consider a firm with a preissue leverage of 0.2, target leverage of 0.21, and an exogenously determined issue size of 0.1. Issuing extra 0.1 of debt increases the firm's debt ratio to about 0.27. Issuing equity reduces the debt ratio to 0.18. Therefore, even though the firm is currently under‐levered, issuing debt results in a much higher deviation from the target than issuing equity.

sec.label: V.
sec.title: Does the Choice of the Proxy for the Target Matter?
sec.p:
The results reported intables 2,3, and 4 are quite strong and appear robust. Is it possible, however, that our use of the industry benchmark as a proxy for the target biases our results? It is also interesting to know whether other proxies for the target would “fit the data” better. In this section, we repeat the analysis using three regression‐based proxies for the target. Hovakimian, et al. (2001) estimate the target leverage ratio as the fitted value from a regression of the following form:
In equation(1), Lev is the leverage ratio andXis the vector of variables thought to proxy the determinants of target leverage. Our set of regressors,X, closely resembles the set of eight firm‐level variables14plus industry effects used by Hovakimian et al. (2001). The only differences are as follows. Instead of the average operating income for the 3 preissue years, we use the operating income in the last pre‐issue year. In addition, the stock return variable is measured over the last pre‐issue year instead of the last pre‐issue year and the year of the issue. These changes increase the number of useful observations and do not affect the results. Finally, following Lie (2002), we add Graham's (1996a,1996b) estimates for marginal tax rate before financing effects as the ninth firm‐level regressor.

Following Hovakimian et al. (2001), we generate three proxies for the target debt ratio.15We obtain our first proxy, Target1, by estimating regression (1) using the full set of regressors. The second proxy, Target2, is derived from the same regression but using a subset of six firm‐level variables as regressors.16To generate the third proxy, Target3, a subset of four firm‐level variables is used.17These regressions produce no new results and are not reported to save space.

sec.label: VI.
sec.title: Multivariate Analysis of the Target Leverage Hypothesis
sec.p: The event‐study results presented in the paper imply that target leverage has little effect on the decision to issue debt or equity. In contrast, prior multivariate studies (e.g., Marsh1982; MacKie‐Mason1990; Bayless and Chaplinsky1991; Hovakimian et al.2001) find that the deviation from target leverage is an important determinant of the issuing (repurchasing) firm's debt‐equity choice. It is possible that, once we control for other firm characteristics in a multivariate regression framework, our results will change dramatically. Another possibility is that our results differ from the results in prior studies because we differentiate “pure” issues and repurchases from the instances when an issue of one security is accompanied by a repurchase of another security.

In this section, we test the two forms of the target leverage hypothesis, formulated earlier in the paper, in multivariate settings. First, we estimate binomial logistic regressions that model the choice between debt and equity, given the firm's decision to issue (repurchase) securities. Such empirical modeling allows us to test the weak form of the target leverage hypothesis that the deviation from the target determines the choice of the form of financing but not necessarily the timing of the financing (the debt‐equity choice hypothesis). To test the strong form of the target leverage hypothesis that the deviation from the target determines both the timing and the form of financing (the target‐adjustment hypothesis), we estimate a multinomial logistic regression that models each of the six issue and repurchase decisions against a no‐transaction alternative.

The set of independent variables in these regressions includes the pre‐issue leverage and the target leverage ratio. If the target leverage hypothesis were correct, we would expect the effect of target leverage on the probability of a leverage‐increasing (decreasing) transaction to be positive (negative) and the effect of the pre‐issue leverage to be negative (positive). The set of independent variables also includes a number of control variables used in earlier studies of debt‐equity choice. Specifically, previous studies find strong links between the firm's capital structure and its market and operating performance. Our measures of market and operating performance are preissue stock return, market‐to‐book ratio, operating income over total assets, and net operating loss carryforward over assets. Following Lie (2002), we also added the level of cash as a control variable. We also experimented with adding Graham's (1996a, 1996b) estimates for marginal tax rate after financing effects into our logistic regressions. Because our main results did not change and to avoid further reduction in the sample size, the reported results exclude this variable.19

fn.p: The tax rate has significantly positive effects on the probability of issuing debt and the probability of repurchasing equity. The marginally significant target leverage in the pure debt issue regression (regression (4) intable 7) becomes insignificant. The results for the sample of pure debt and equity issues are inconsistent with the findings of earlier studies that security issues offset the deviation from the target leverage. The coefficient estimates for both the target and the pre‐issue leverage ratio are insignificant. In contrast, the results for the full sample of security issues are consistent with both the target leverage hypothesis and the results of earlier studies. The coefficient estimate for the preissue debt ratio is negative. The coefficient estimate for the target ratio is positive. Both estimates are statistically significant at the 1% level.

Regardless of the sample used, the results for debt and equity repurchases are consistent with the hypothesis that the security being repurchased is chosen to offset the accumulated deviation from the target leverage. The coefficient estimate for the target is negative and statistically significant, while the coefficient for the preissue leverage is positive significant.

Other interesting results are as follows. First, in both the pure issue sample and the full sample with mixed transactions, firms with high market‐to‐book ratios and high stock returns are more likely to issue equity than debt. This is consistent with both the trade‐off hypothesis that high‐growth firms have low target debt ratios and the market‐timing hypothesis that firms issue equity following periods of high market performance, when they are more likely to be overpriced. However, the insignificance of other trade‐off variables (pre‐issue leverage, target leverage, and operating performance) in the pure debt vs. pure equity choice regression leads us to believe that the significance of market performance is more likely to be related to market timing.

The effect of operating performance on the debt vs. equity issue choice depends on the sample used. Operating performance (ROA and NOLC) has no effect in the pure debt vs. pure equity trade‐off. On the other hand, the probability of debt vs. equity issuance increases with operating performance when the debt vs. equity choice model is estimated on the sample consisting of all debt and equity issues. This implies that the positive effect of operating performance on the probability of debt vis‐à‐vis equity issuance, documented in earlier studies, is driven by firms that repurchase securities in the year of the issue.

The signs and the significance of all the explanatory variables in the debt reduction vs. equity repurchase model are the same for both samples. The results intable 6, along with the univariate results intable 1, imply that firms with high operating performance are more likely to repurchase equity, while firms with low operating performance are more likely to retire debt. These results are consistent with the prediction of the trade‐off theory of capital structure that more profitable firms have higher target debt ratios. The results are not consistent with the prediction of the pecking order theory that firms should borrow when their cash flows are low and retire debt when their cash flows are high.

High market‐to‐book firms are more likely to repurchase equity than to retire debt. This result is not consistent with either the trade‐off or the pecking order hypothesis. A look attable 1reveals that the equity repurchasers' market‐to‐book ratios are indeed higher than the ratios of firms that retire debt but lower than the equity issuers' ratios. Perhaps equity repurchasers are high market‐to‐book firms that experience short‐term declines in market performance.

Finally, the results inTable 6imply that firms with high cash levels are more likely to issue equity than debt and more likely to repurchase equity than to retire debt. A look attable 1confirms that firms initiating equity transactions (either issue or repurchase) have significantly higher cash levels than firms initiating debt transactions (either issue or reduction). In addition, low leverage ratios of equity issuers and repurchasers intable 1indicate that these firms rely heavily on equity financing. One possibility is that high cash levels allow firms that rely on equity financing to time equity issues to the periods when the indirect costs of issuing equity (costs of adverse selection and perceived underpricing) are relatively low.

To summarize, the results intable 6confirm our earlier conclusions that the target debt ratio plays no major role in the debt and equity issuance decisions but is an important factor in the decision to retire debt. Our results also indicate that the importance of deviation from target leverage found in prior studies of debt‐equity choice is driven by the subsample of security issues accompanied by security repurchases.

fn.p: Because of the missing values of the explanatory variables, we have fewer observations intable 6than in tables3and4.

sec.title: The Target‐Adjustment Hypothesis
sec.p:
The results of the multinomial logit model estimating the probability of issuing or repurchasing debt or equity against a no‐transaction alternative are presented intable 7. Consistent with the target leverage hypothesis, the probability of retiring debt (with and without an accompanying equity issue) increases with preissue leverage and declines with target leverage. In contrast, both the target and the preissue leverage are insignificant in the equity issue model. In the debt issue model, the target is positive and significant, as expected. However, the pre‐issue leverage is also positive and statistically significant, implying that firms with high leverage tend to issue more debt. This result is consistent with our event‐study findings but not consistent with the hypothesis that firms revert to the target. The probability of an equity repurchase is higher for firms with low prerepurchase leverage. However, the effect of the target debt ratio is insignificant, which is inconsistent with the target leverage hypothesis. The results for equity repurchases accompanied by debt issues are insignificant, which may be partly due to the low number of observations in this group. To summarize, multinomial logit analysis modeling the probability of issuing or repurchasing debt or equity against a no‐transaction alternative confirms our event‐study conclusions that the deviation from the target debt ratio is an important determinant of the decision to retire debt but does not play a major role in the debt issuance, equity issuance, and equity repurchase decisions.

sec.label: VII.
sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The concept of target capital structure plays an important role in many models of corporate financing. However, empirical evidence on target leverage has been mixed. This study suggests that the conflicting results arise partially because the importance and the role played by target leverage vary across different types of corporate financing transactions. The paper addresses this issue by formulating and testing two hypotheses about the role of target leverage in security issuance and repurchase decisions. These hypotheses are tested separately for debt issues, equity issues, debt reductions, and equity repurchases, allowing us to infer which, if any, of these corporate financing events is more likely to be driven by target leverage considerations.

The picture emerging from the paper is that firms that issue or repurchase equity generally have low debt ratios. We find that firms do not initiate equity transactions to offset the accumulated deviation from the target leverage ratio. Equity issuers tend to be underlevered prior to the issue and become even more underlevered as a result of the issue. Changes in leverage induced by equity issues are relatively transitory and offset by a postissue upward drift in leverage. Equity repurchases, on the other hand, follow periods of increasing leverage deficit but fail to induce a significant change in leverage.

The timing of equity transactions appears to be driven by market conditions. Equity is issued following periods of improvement in both market and operating performance. Equity is repurchased following periods when, despite strong operating performance, stock returns are relatively low.

Even though market conditions appear to have an important effect on the timing of equity transactions, we do not believe that the capital structure is irrelevant for these firms. These firms prefer equity transactions precisely because they have low target debt ratios. Throughout the 7‐year period examined in the paper, the debt ratios of firms that issue or repurchase equity remain significantly low. Furthermore, these firms are able to pursue market‐timing strategies because the deviations (and the costs of deviating) from the target induced by equity transactions are very small. In fact, an average equity issuer (repurchaser) would deviate further from the target if it raised (repurchased) the same amount of debt.

Firms that issue or retire debt have relatively high debt ratios throughout the 7‐year period studied in the paper. We find that debt issuers do not have a significant accumulated deviation from the target that needs to be offset. Nevertheless, debt issues induce economically and statistically significant increases in leverage. The resulting debt ratios are significantly higher than the target. In fact, an average debt issuer would remain closer to the target, if it issued equity instead. Debt issuers remain significantly overlevered for more than 3 years after the issue. One interpretation of these results is that debt issuers respond to an increase in their target leverage, which our proxies for the target are unable to capture.

Among the transactions examined in the paper, only debt reductions are used to adjust the firm's leverage toward its target ratio. In the years preceding the transaction, these firms experienced economically and statistically significant increases in excess leverage along with deterioration in market and operating performance. The accumulated excess leverage is offset as a result of the transaction. The resulting lower debt ratios persist over the 3‐year postevent period examined in the paper.

Multivariate analysis of the debt‐equity issue choice using logistic regressions confirms our event‐study results. Specifically, it demonstrates that the importance of the deviation from target leverage in earlier studies of debt‐equity choice is driven by the subsample of equity issues accompanied by debt reductions.
